item.paragraph: Notes:
(US UE Arterial Duplex Right) Reason For Exam: ischemic hand fingers;Other, (Free text in Reason for Exam field)

paragraph.content:
PROCEDURE: US UE Arterial Duplex Right.
TECHNIQUE: Multiple real-time grayscale images were obtained over the right
upper extremity in various projections. Additional duplex Doppler and color
Doppler images were also obtained.
INDICATION: 53-year-old female with a right arm dialysis fistula, presents with
right hand and right finger ischemic changes.
COMPARISONS: CTA right upper extremity 2023-07-21
FINDINGS:
The vessels are heavily calcified limiting assessment. There is triphasic flow
in the right subclavian artery with normal flow velocities. Flow becomes
monophasic in the axillary artery where there is elevated flow velocity in the
proximal brachial artery suggesting hemodynamically significant stenosis. There
is diminished flow velocities in the ulnar artery with normal flow velocity in
the radial artery but the waveform is monophasic.
IMPRESSION:
Heavily calcified vessels throughout the right upper extremity. There is
elevated flow velocities in the right brachial artery proximally suggesting
possible hemodynamically significant stenosis. The flow is triphasic in the
subclavian artery but monophasic in the entirety of the right arm including the
axilla, brachial, ulnar and radial arteries.
Dictated on workstation:X585-3853-7080

***** Final *****
Dictated by: Reddy, Suryakumar V M
Dictated DT/TM: 2023-07-21 7:40 pm
Signed by: Reddy, Suryakumar V MD

text.paragraph: No data available for this section

Hemodialysis
Hemodialysis is a procedure in which the blood is filtered with a machine and a filter called a dialyzer. Hemodialysis is one type of dialysis, which is a procedure that replaces some of the work that healthy kidneys do. During dialysis, wastes, salt, and extra water are removed from the blood, and the level of certain important minerals in the blood is maintained. Dialysis is normally started when a person has lost about 85–90% of kidney function, or earlier if it may help relieve symptoms.
Hemodialysis is usually done by a health care provider at a hospital or dialysis center 3 times a week for 3–5 hours during each visit. With training, you may be able to do it at home on a different schedule.
Tell a health care provider about:
• Any allergies you have.
• All medicines you are taking, including vitamins, herbs, eye drops, creams, and over-the-counter medicines.
• Any blood disorders you have.
• Any surgeries you have had.
• Any medical conditions you have.
What are the risks?
Generally, this is a safe procedure. However, problems may occur, including:
• Low blood pressure (hypotension).
• An infection or blockage at the site where blood is removed from the body and returned to the body (vascular access site).
• Allergic reaction to chemicals used to clean (sterilize) the dialyzer.
• Narrowing or ballooning of a blood vessel, or bleeding at the vascular access site. This is rare.
What happens before the procedure?
Medicines
Ask your health care provider about:
• Changing or stopping your regular medicines. This is especially important if you are taking diabetes medicines or blood thinners.
• Taking medicines such as aspirin and ibuprofen. These medicines can thin your blood. Do not take these medicines unless your health care provider tells you to take them.
• Taking over-the-counter medicines, vitamins, herbs, and supplements.
General instructions
• Before having hemodialysis for the first time, a surgery or procedure will be done to create a vascular access site. There are three types of vascular access:
◦ Arteriovenous fistula. This type is created when an artery and a vein, often in the arm, are connected through surgery. This type of vascular access usually takes 1–6 months to develop after surgery.
◦ Arteriovenous graft. This type is created when a tube is used to connect an artery and a vein in the arm. This type of vascular access can usually be used within 2–3 weeks of surgery.
◦ A venous catheter. To create this type, a long, thin tube (catheter) is placed in a large vein in your neck, chest, or groin. A venous catheter can be used right away.
• Follow instructions from your health care provider about eating or drinking restrictions.
• Ask your health care provider what steps will be taken to prevent infection.
What happens during the procedure?
• Your weight, blood pressure, pulse, and temperature will be measured.
• Your vascular access will be connected to the dialyzer.
◦ If your access is a fistula or graft, two needles will be inserted through the vascular access. The needles will be connected to a plastic tube that is connected to the dialyzer. They will be taped to your skin so that they do not move out of place.
◦ If your access is a catheter, it will be connected to a plastic tube that is then connected to the dialyzer.
• The dialysis machine will be turned on. This will cause your blood to flow to the dialyzer. The dialyzer will filter and clean your blood before returning it to your body. While the dialysis machine is working, your blood pressure and pulse will be checked several times.
• When dialysis is complete, your vascular access will be disconnected from the plastic tube. If your access is a fistula or graft, the needles will be removed and a bandage (dressing) will be placed over the access.
This procedure is done while you are sitting or reclining with your legs raised (elevated). During the procedure, you may sleep, read, watch TV, or do other tasks that can be done while you are in this position. It is important to stay in this position. Let your health care provider know if you have side effects or any other discomfort during the procedure. Adjustments may be made to help you feel more comfortable.
The procedure may vary among health care providers and hospitals.
What happens after the procedure?
• Your blood pressure, heart rate, breathing rate, and blood oxygen level will be monitored until you leave the hospital or clinic.
• Your weight will be measured.
• You may have or continue to have side effects, including:
◦ Dizziness.
◦ Muscle cramps.
◦ Nausea.
◦ Headaches.
◦ Allergic reaction to the chemicals used to sterilize the dialyzer.
Where to find more information
National Kidney Foundation: https://www.williams-williams.com/
Summary
• Hemodialysis is a procedure in which the blood is filtered with a machine and a filter called a dialyzer. Dialysis is a procedure that replaces some of the work that healthy kidneys do.
• Hemodialysis is usually done by a health care provider at a hospital or dialysis center 3 times a week for 3–5 hours during each visit.
• Before having this procedure for the first time, you will need surgery or a procedure to create a vascular access site.
• During hemodialysis, the dialyzer will remove wastes, salt, and extra water from your blood before returning it to your body.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2021-10-10 Document Reviewed: 2021-04-18
Elsevier Patient Education © 2021 Elsevier Inc.

Dialysis Fistulogram, Care After
The following information offers guidance on how to care for yourself after your procedure. Your health care provider may also give you more specific instructions. If you have problems or questions, contact your health care provider.
What can I expect after the procedure?
After the procedure, it is common to have:
• A small amount of discomfort in the area where the small tube (catheter) was placed for the procedure.
• A small amount of bruising around the fistula.
• Sleepiness and tiredness (fatigue).
Follow these instructions at home:
Puncture site care
• Follow instructions from your health care provider about how to take care of the site where catheters were inserted. Make sure you:
◦ Wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds before and after you change your bandage (dressing). If soap and water are not available, use hand sanitizer.
◦ Change your dressing as told by your health care provider.
◦ Leave stitches (sutures), skin glue, or adhesive strips in place. These skin closures may need to stay in place for 2 weeks or longer. If adhesive strip edges start to loosen and curl up, you may trim the loose edges. Do not remove adhesive strips completely unless your health care provider tells you to do that.
• Check your puncture area every day for signs of infection. Check for:
◦ More redness, swelling, or pain.
◦ Fluid or blood.
◦ Warmth.
◦ Pus or a bad smell.
Activity
• Rest as much as you can.
• If you were given a sedative during the procedure, it can affect you for several hours. Do not drive or operate machinery until your health care provider says that it is safe.
• Do not lift anything that is heavier than 5 lb (2.3 kg), or the limit that you are told, on the day of your procedure.
• Do not do anything strenuous with your arm for the rest of the day. Avoid household activities, such as vacuuming.
• Return to your normal activities as told by your health care provider. Ask your health care provider what activities are safe for you.
Safety
To prevent damage to your graft or fistula:
• Do not wear tight-fitting clothing or jewelry on the arm or leg that has your graft or fistula.
• Tell all your health care providers that you have a dialysis fistula or graft.
• Do not allow blood draws, IVs, or blood pressure readings to be done in the arm that has your fistula or graft.
• Do not allow flu shots or vaccinations in the arm with your fistula or graft.
General instructions
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
• Do not take baths, swim, or use a hot tub until your health care provider approves. Ask your health care provider if you may take showers. You may only be allowed to take sponge baths.
• Monitor your dialysis fistula closely. Check to make sure that you can feel a vibration or buzz (a thrill) when you put your fingers over the fistula.
• Keep all follow-up visits. This is important.
Contact a health care provider if:
• You have more redness, swelling, or pain at the site where the catheter was put in.
• You have fluid or blood coming from the catheter site.
• You have pus or a bad smell coming from the catheter site.
• Your catheter site feels warm.
• You have a fever or chills.
Get help right away if:
• You have bleeding from the vascular access site that does not stop.
• You feel weak.
• You have trouble balancing.
• You have trouble moving your arms or legs.
• You have problems with your speech or vision.
• You can no longer feel a vibration or buzz when you put your fingers over your fistula.
• The limb that was used for the procedure swells or becomes painful, cold, blue, or pale white.
• You have chest pain or shortness of breath.
These symptoms may represent a serious problem that is an emergency. Do not wait to see if the symptoms will go away. Get medical help right away. Call your local emergency services (911 in the U.S.). Do not drive yourself to the hospital.
Summary
• After a dialysis fistulogram, it is common to have a small amount of discomfort or bruising in the area where the small, thin tube (catheter) was placed.
• Rest as much as you can after your procedure. Return to your normal activities as told by your health care provider.
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
• Follow instructions from your health care provider about how to take care of the site where the catheter was inserted.
• Keep all follow-up visits. This is important.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2022-03-28 Document Reviewed: 2022-03-28
Elsevier Patient Education © 2022 Elsevier Inc.

Dialysis
Dialysis is a procedure that is done when the kidneys have stopped working properly (kidney failure). It may also be done earlier if it may help improve symptoms. During dialysis, wastes, salt, and extra water are removed from the blood, and the levels of certain minerals in the blood are maintained.
Dialysis is done in sessions that are continued until the kidneys get better. If the kidneys cannot get better, such as in end-stage kidney disease, dialysis is continued for life or until you receive a new kidney from a donor (kidney transplant).
Types of treatments
There are two types of dialysis: hemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis. Both types of dialysis have advantages and disadvantages. Talk with your health care provider about which type of dialysis is best for you. Your lifestyle, preferences, and medical condition will be considered. In some cases, only one type of dialysis can be chosen.
Hemodialysis
Hemodialysis is when blood is filtered with a machine and a filter called a dialyzer. This treatment is usually done at a hospital or dialysis center three times per week. Visits last about 3–5 hours.
• Before you start hemodialysis treatment, you will have minor surgery to create a vascular access point. Your vascular access will be where you'll connect to the dialyzer.
• Home hemodialysis may also be an option for some patients. This means that hemodialysis can be performed at home with the help of a family member or caregiver who has had special training.
Peritoneal dialysis
Peritoneal dialysis is when the thin lining of the abdomen (peritoneum) and a fluid called dialysate are used to filter the blood.
• Before you start peritoneal dialysis, a surgeon places a soft tube, called a catheter, in your belly.
• You may do peritoneal dialysis at home or at almost any other location. After training, most people can perform both types of peritoneal dialysis on their own.
• You may need up to five exchanges a day. Each exchange takes about 30–40 minutes. The amount of time the dialysate is in your body between exchanges is called a dwell. The dwell usually lasts 1.5–3 hours and can vary with each person. You may choose to do exchanges at night while you sleep, using a machine called a cycler.
What are the advantages?
Advantages of hemodialysis
• It is done less often than peritoneal dialysis.
• Someone else can do the dialysis for you.
• If you go to a dialysis center:
◦ Your health care provider can recognize any problems you may be having.
◦ You can interact with others who are having dialysis. This can provide you with emotional support.
Advantages of peritoneal dialysis
• It is less likely than hemodialysis to cause cramps and low blood pressure.
• There are fewer eating restrictions than with hemodialysis.
• You may do exchanges on your own wherever you are, including when you travel.
• If you do automated peritoneal dialysis, you can set up your cycler every night.
What are the disadvantages
Disadvantages of hemodialysis
Generally, hemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis are safe treatments. However, problems may occur.
• Cramps and low blood pressure. It may leave you feeling tired on the days you have the treatment.
• The need to make weekly appointments and work around the center's schedule, if you go to a dialysis center.
• The need to take extra care when traveling. If you usually get treatment in a dialysis center, you will need to arrange to visit a dialysis center near your destination. If you are having treatments at home, you will need to take the dialyzer with you when traveling.
• More eating restrictions than with peritoneal dialysis.
Disadvantages of peritoneal dialysis
• More frequent treatments than with hemodialysis.
• The need to have a good use (dexterity) of your hands. You must also be able to lift bags.
• The need to learn how to make your equipment free of germs (sterilization techniques). You will need to use these techniques every day to prevent infection.
What happens before the treatment?
Hemodialysis
Before starting hemodialysis, you will have minor surgery to create a site where blood can be removed from your body and returned to your body (vascular access). There are three types of vascular accesses:
• Arteriovenous (AV) fistula. This type of access is created when an artery and a vein (usually in the arm) are connected during surgery. The AV fistula also has a large diameter that allows your blood to flow out and back into your body quickly. The goal is to allow high blood flow so that the largest amount of blood can pass through the dialyzer. The arteriovenous fistula usually takes 1–6 months to develop after surgery. It may last longer than the other types of vascular accesses and is less likely to become infected or cause blood clots.
• Arteriovenous graft. If problems with your veins prevent you from having an AV fistula, you may need an AV graft instead. This type of access is created when an artery and a vein in the arm are connected during surgery with a tube. An arteriovenous graft can usually be used within 2–3 weeks of surgery.
• A venous catheter. To create this type of access, a thin tube (catheter) is placed in a large vein in your neck, chest, or groin. A venous catheter can be used right away. It is usually used as a short-term access when dialysis needs to be started right away.
Peritoneal dialysis
Before starting peritoneal dialysis, you will have surgery to place a catheter in your abdomen. The catheter will be used to transfer a solution called dialysate to and from your abdomen.
What happens during the treatment?
Hemodialysis
During hemodialysis, blood will leave your body through your vascular access site. Blood will travel through a tube to the dialyzer, where it is filtered. The blood will then return to your body through a different tube.
Peritoneal dialysis
At the start of a dialysis session, your abdomen will be filled with dialysate solution. During dialysis, waste, salt, and extra water in the blood will pass through the peritoneum and into the dialysate solution. The dialysate solution will be drained from the body at the end of the dialysis session. The process of filling and draining the dialysate is called an exchange. Exchanges are repeated until you have used up all of the dialysate solution for that day.
Follow these instructions at home:
Eating and drinking
• Make changes to your diet as told by your health care provider, such as:
◦ Limiting your intake of foods that contain a lot of phosphorus and potassium.
◦ Limiting your fluid and salt intake.
◦ Add protein to your diet because dialysis removes protein.
• Work with a diet and nutrition specialist (dietitian) to make a meal plan that can help improve your dialysis and your health and healthy ways to add calories to your diet because you may not have a good appetite.
• Take vitamins made for people with kidney failure.
Activity
• Rest as told by your health care provider. You may have less energy.
• You may need to limit some physical activities when your belly is full of dialysis solution.
• Return to your normal activities as told by your health care provider. Ask your health care provider what activities are safe for you.
General instructions
• Try to adjust to the dialysis treatment, schedule, and diet. This can take some time. You may need to stop working and may not be able to do some of your normal activities.
• You may feel anxious or depressed when starting dialysis. Over time, many people feel better overall because of dialysis. You may be able to return to work after making some changes, such as reducing work intensity.
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
• Keep all follow-up visits. This is important.
Where to find more information
• National Kidney Foundation: https://www.williams-williams.com/
• American Association of Kidney Patients: https://welch.net/
• American Kidney Fund: https://www.morales.com/
Summary
• During dialysis, wastes, salt, and extra water are removed from the blood, and the levels of certain minerals in the blood are maintained. There are two types of dialysis: hemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis.
• Hemodialysis is when the blood is filtered with a machine and a filter called a dialyzer.
• Peritoneal dialysis is when the peritoneum is used as a filter. You may do peritoneal dialysis at home or at almost any other location.
• Both types of dialysis have advantages and disadvantages. Talk with your health care provider about which type of dialysis is best for you.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2022-03-13 Document Reviewed: 2022-03-13
Elsevier Patient Education © 2022 Elsevier Inc.

End-Stage Kidney Disease
End-stage kidney disease occurs when the kidneys are so damaged that they cannot function and cannot get better. This condition may also be referred to as end-stage renal disease or ESRD. The kidneys are two organs that do many important jobs in the body, including:
• Removing waste and extra fluid from the blood to make urine.
• Making hormones that maintain the amount of fluid in tissues and blood vessels.
• Maintaining the right amount of fluids and chemicals in the body.
Without functioning kidneys, toxins build up in the blood, and life-threatening complications can occur.
What are the causes?
This condition usually occurs when a long-term (chronic) kidney disease gets worse and results in permanent damage to the kidneys. It may also be caused by sudden damage to the kidneys (acute kidney injury).
What increases the risk?
The following factors may make you more likely to develop this condition:
• Having a family history of chronic kidney disease (CKD).
• Chronic medical conditions that affect the kidneys, such as:
◦ Cardiovascular disease, including high blood pressure.
◦ Diabetes.
◦ Certain diseases that affect the body's disease-fighting Baker (immunesystem).
• Smoking or a history of smoking.
• Overuse of over-the-counter pain medicines.
• Being around or being in contact with poisonous (toxic) substances.
What are the signs or symptoms?
Symptoms of this condition include:
• Swelling of the face, legs, ankles, or feet.
• Numbness, tingling, or loss of feeling in the hands or feet.
• Tiredness (lethargy).
• Nausea or vomiting.
• Confusion, trouble concentrating, or loss of consciousness.
• Chest pain.
• Shortness of breath.
• Passing little or no urine.
• Muscle twitches and cramps, especially in the legs.
• Skin changes, such as:
◦ Dry, itchy skin.
◦ Pale skin due to anemia, including the skin and tissue around the eye (conjunctiva).
◦ Abnormally dark or light skin.
• Loss of appetite.
• Headaches.
• Decrease in muscle size (muscle wasting).
• Easy bruising.
• Stopping of menstrual periods, in women.
• Jerky movements (seizures).
How is this diagnosed?
This condition may be diagnosed based on:
• A physical exam, including blood pressure measurements.
• Urine tests.
• Blood tests.
• Imaging tests.
• A test in which a sample of tissue is removed from the kidneys to be examined under a microscope (kidney biopsy).
How is this treated?
This condition may be treated with:
• Dialysis, which is a procedure that removes toxic wastes from the body. There are two types of dialysis:
◦ Dialysis that is done through your abdomen. This is called peritoneal dialysis and may be done several times a day.
◦ Dialysis that is done by a machine. This is called hemodialysis and may be done several times a week.
• Kidney transplant. This is surgery to receive a new kidney.
In addition to having dialysis or a kidney transplant, you may need to take medicines:
• To control high blood pressure (hypertension).
• To control high cholesterol.
• To treat diabetes.
• To maintain healthy levels of minerals in the blood (electrolytes).
You may also be given a specific meal plan to follow that includes requirements or limits for:
• Salt (sodium).
• Protein.
• Phosphorus.
• Potassium.
• Calcium.
Follow these instructions at home:
Medicines
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
• Do not take any new medicines, vitamins, or mineral supplements unless approved by your health care provider. Many medicines and supplements can worsen kidney damage.
• Follow instructions from your health care provider about adjusting the doses of any medicines you take.
Lifestyle
• Do not use any products that contain nicotine or tobacco, such as cigarettes, e-cigarettes, and chewing tobacco. If you need help quitting, ask your health care provider.
• Achieve and maintain a healthy weight. If you need help with this, ask your health care provider.
• Start or continue an exercise plan. Exercise at least 30 minutes a day, 5 days a week.
• Follow your prescribed meal plan.
General instructions
• Stay current with your shots (immunizations) as told by your health care provider.
• Keep track of your blood pressure. Report changes in your blood pressure as told by your health care provider.
• If you are being treated for diabetes, monitor and track your blood sugar (blood glucose) levels as told by your health care provider.
• Keep all follow-up visits. This is important.
Where to find more information
• American Association of Kidney Patients: https://welch.net/
• National Kidney Foundation: https://www.williams-williams.com/
• American Kidney Fund: https://www.jackson.net/
• Life Options Rehabilitation Program: https://www.williams-graham.com/
• Kidney School: https://carroll-martinez.info/
Contact a health care provider if:
• Your symptoms get worse.
• You develop new symptoms.
Get help right away if:
• You have weakness in an arm or leg on one side of your body.
• You have difficulty speaking or you are slurring your speech.
• You have a sudden change in your vision.
• You have a sudden, severe headache.
• You have a sudden weight increase.
• You have difficulty breathing.
• Your symptoms suddenly get worse.
• You have chest pain.
Summary
• End-stage kidney disease occurs when the kidneys are so damaged that they cannot function and cannot get better.
• Without functioning kidneys, toxins build up in the blood and life-threatening complications can occur.
• Treatment may include dialysis or a kidney transplant along with medicines and lifestyle changes.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2021-12-12 Document Reviewed: 2021-11-19
Elsevier Patient Education © 2022 Elsevier Inc.

Traumatic Finger Amputation
A traumatic finger amputation is when a person loses part or all of a finger because of an accident or injury. This condition is a medical emergency. It needs to be treated right away to prevent more damage to the finger and to save the lost part of the finger, if that is possible.
What are the causes?
This condition usually results from an accident that involves:
• A car.
• Power tools.
• Factory work.
• Farm or lawn equipment.
What are the signs or symptoms?
Symptoms of this condition include:
• Bleeding.
• Pain.
• Damage to surrounding tissues, such as bones, muscles, tendons, and skin.
How is this diagnosed?
This condition is diagnosed with a physical exam. During the exam, your health care provider will determine how severe the injury is and the best way to treat it. X-rays may be done to check for damage to the surrounding bones and tissues.
How is this treated?
This condition is treated by cleaning the wound thoroughly and with medicines for pain. Additional treatment depends on the type of injury that you have and how bad it is:
• If only the tip of your finger was removed, treatment may involve placing a protective bandage (dressing) over the wound and cleaning the wound regularly.
• If the injury is severe, a portion of skin may be taken from another part of the body (graft) and attached to the wound site until the wound heals.
• If a large portion of the finger was cut off, treatment may include a surgical procedure to reattach the finger (replantation).
Follow these instructions at home:
Medicines
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
• If you were prescribed an antibiotic medicine, use it as told by your health care provider. Do not stop using the antibiotic even if your condition improves.
• Do not drive or use heavy machinery while taking prescription pain medicine.
Wound care
• Follow instructions from your health care provider about how to take care of your wound. Make sure you:
◦ Wash your hands with soap and water before you change your dressing. If soap and water are not available, use hand sanitizer.
◦ Change your dressing as told by your health care provider.
◦ Leave stitches (sutures), skin glue, or adhesive strips in place. These skin closures may need to stay in place for 2 weeks or longer. If adhesive strip edges start to loosen and curl up, you may trim the loose edges. Do not remove adhesive strips completely unless your health care provider tells you to do that.
• Check your wound every day for signs of infection. Check for:
◦ Redness, swelling, or pain.
◦ Fluid or blood.
◦ Warmth.
◦ Pus or a bad smell.
General instructions
• Do exercises to strengthen your finger and hand as directed by your health care provider.
• Keep your hand raised above the level of your heart when resting.
Contact a health care provider if:
• Your wound does not seem to be healing well.
• You have redness, swelling, or pain around your wound.
• You have fluid or blood coming from your wound.
• Your wound feels warm to the touch.
• You have pus or a bad smell coming from your wound.
• You have a fever.
Get help right away if:
• You have redness spreading or extending from your wound.
Summary
• A traumatic finger amputation is when a person loses part or all of a finger because of an accident or injury.
• This condition is diagnosed with a physical exam. During the exam your health care provider will determine how severe the injury is and the best way to treat it.
• Follow instructions from your health care provider about how to take care of your wound.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.

HPI/Reason for Hospitalization
53-year-old female with PMH of ESRD (HD Tu/Thu/Sa), T2DM, COPD, chronic bilateral lower extremity wounds, and right BKA admitted for gangrene of R 4th and 5th fingers and calciphylaxis of right hypothenar eminence. Patient complains of progressively worsening pain in right hypothenar eminence and right 4th and 5th fingers of one week duration. She follows with WMC outpatient wound team and was recently evaluated by them. She was also seen by WMC ED yesterday for same chief complaint and was discharged on same day. Patient reports she had her RUE AV fistula reviewed by Dr. Woolard 6 days ago to increase blood flow to right 4th and 5th fingers. She does not report improvement in her symptoms since this intervention. She also complains of night sweats but denies fever and chills and was afebrile in ED. She also complains of nausea. She completed HD today. In the ED, LA was normal and CTA RUE and RUE Duplex US showed heavily calcified distal radial and ulnar arteries with possible hemodynamically significant stenosis. ED provider consulted hand surgeon, vascular surgeon, and nephrologist. Due to gangrene and increased risk of sepsis, patient was started on broad antibiotics. Home plavix held for potential amputation of right fourth and fifth fingers.
Hospital Course with Significant Findings
Patient underwent amputation of 4th and 5th fingers at MCP on 11/29. Post-op course was uncomplicated. She was on abx for 8 days post op and had no infection or signs of poor wound healing. Patient will need wound care at SNU. Patient is very agreeable to SNU.

Amputation of the 4th and 5th fingers at MCP

Cook Brandon MD: PERFORM
Event Display: Operative Report
Authored Date: 20230729204941-0600

Indication for Surgery: 53-year-old who comes at this time due to ischemia of the right hand. She has a fistula in the right hand with significant loss of blood flow to the ring and small finger. She recently had the fistula ligated. She has demarcation of a good portion of the ring and small finger and portions of the ulnar side of the hand. I discussed with her at length prior to the operation about the poor blood sugar management and poor vascularity of the hand. I discussed with her that it is my hope that we can salvage the radial side of the hand with soft tissue reconstruction and removal of the ring and small finger. We discussed that due to her poor vascular flow in the hand she may have some delayed healing. We talked about the risks and benefits of a partial amputation of the hand. We will proceed with ray resection of the ring and small finger.
Preoperative Diagnosis: 1. Ischemia right hand
Postoperative Diagnosis: Same
Operation: Ray resection of ring and small finger right hand
Surgeon Primary: Brandon. Linnell
Assistant: Parker Zimmerman, MD
Anesthesia General anesthesia estimated Blood Loss: 5ml
Findings: Good blood flow in the flap edges after amputation
Complications: None
Technique: After informed consent was obtained the patient was taken to the operating room and placed in the operating room table in the supine position. The patient was placed under general anesthesia. The right arm was scrubbed with alcohol and then prepped and draped in the sterile fashion. An incision line was marked out around the areas of obvious demarcation. This was incised with a 10 blade through the skin into the subcutaneous tissue and cauterization was used to raise the necrotic tissue off of the metacarpals at the fourth and fifth metacarpals. This was done with cautery at 30. The nonviable tissue was taken up to the MCP joint of the small and ring finger where these digits were removed at the MCP joint. Once the necrotic tissue was removed the area was washed out copiously with 3 L of irrigation. The metacarpals were exposed more proximally by raising the soft tissues carefully off the metacarpals down to the base of the fourth and fifth metacarpals. Osteotomy was performed with a sagittal saw of each of these metacarpals at the base and they were removed carefully. Hemostasis was gained. Skin flaps were tailored and there was good healthy bleeding from the edges. There was capillary refill from the skin around the edges. This was loosely closed with chromic suture.
Postop: Absorbable sutures. No need for removal. Follow-up in 1 week. Continue antibiotics for 10 days postop.

Event Display: Operative Report
Authored Date: 20230723-0600

Date of Procedure: 2023-07-23
SURGEON:
Chad Ammar, MD.
ASSISTANT:
Carlin Hill, PGY1.
PROCEDURE:
Right upper extremity AV fistula ligation.
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES:
1. Ischemic necrosis, right hand including the digits extending in the palm including the skin and subcutaneous tissue.
2. End-stage renal disease, on hemodialysis.
3. Type 2 diabetes, insulin-dependent.
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES:
1. Ischemic necrosis, right hand including the digits extending in the palm including the skin and subcutaneous tissue.
2. End-stage renal disease, on hemodialysis.
3. Type 2 diabetes, insulin-dependent.
ANESTHESIA:
General.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS:
10 mL
BLOOD PRODUCTS GIVEN:
None.
URINE OUTPUT:
Not monitored.
TUBES AND DRAINS:
None.
DEVICE IMPLANTS:
None.
SPECIMENS:
None.
COMPLICATIONS:
None.
CONDITION:
Stable throughout.
FINDINGS:
Monophasic Doppler signals in the ulnar position with a weak monophasic palmar arch signal with slight augmentation with fistula ligation.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient is a 53-year-old female who had a right upper extremity AV fistula revision done by my partner. This was accompanied by plication nearly a week ago. She has had worsening ischemia to her right hand. Noninvasive imaging was performed including CTA of the hand as well as arterial ultrasound. I did have a discussion with the patient about risks of limb loss, regardless of whether we ligate the fistula or not, but I did feel that her only chance of limb salvage and saving as much knee as possible and to ligate the fistula. She was agreeable to this and understood the risks, benefits and alternatives including but not limited to risk of bleeding, infection, thrombosis, embolization, nerve injury, risk for major limb loss, heart attack, stroke and even death. She agreed to proceed.
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE:
After consent was obtained, the patient was taken to the operating room and placed supine. General anesthesia was induced. Time-out was performed. The area was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. Attention was directed to the right upper extremity. Sterile ultrasound was brought to the field and the AV anastomosis was identified. I reopened the previous incision, dissecting down to the AV anastomosis. I did Doppler and ultrasound interrogation of the outflow vessels with color flow as well. There was modest augmentation with fistula compression. She did have a monophasic ulnar signal with and without fistula compression, but it did augment. At the wrist position, there was a palmar arch signal that did have slight augmentation with fistula compression. Due to this, I thought the best chance of limb salvage would be to ligate the fistula. A 2-0 silk sutures were used to ligate the fistula at the AV anastomosis. This resulted in cessation of flow through the fistula. Meticulous hemostasis confirmed. The deep dermal layer was closed using 3-0 Vicryl. Skin was closed with staples. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was sent to recovery room in stable condition. I did update Dr. Linnell, who is on the case for hand surgery.

spoke with the medical Doctor last night about patients condition. She was very lethargic, confused, agitated to start the shift. Her blood sugars were trending low and her HR was in the 50s. She also expressed concern about her right fingers/hand worsening. was told that surgery is tentatively planned for Monday on her right hand. Dr agreed it was good to hold the scheduled narcotics and that it was good that I held her Lyrica and metoprolol due to her low HR and lethargy. currently giving Tylenol for pain instead for now. pt was coughing when trying to take pills with water so I ended up crushing them in pudding and she took them better that way. initiated telemetry and she is running sinus brady per rhythm central. pt - in her confusion - keeps removing/adjusting her right hand dressing. she also has these occasional tremors/jerks that she says she's had for a long time. Pt also has a productive/persistent cough. We have checked pts blood sugar multiple times through the night due to it being low, but after multiple treatments (IV and PO), pt has maintained her blood sugar around 100 that last couple times.
around 0300 patient is starting to become more alert, responsive, and less agitated and confused. She is more aware of what is going on and asking appropriate questions about her care. will continue to monitor her status and vital signs/blood sugar closely.

She follows with WMC outpatient wound team and was recently evaluated by them. She was also seen by WMC ED recently for same chief complaint and was discharged on same day.

History of Present Illness
53-year-old female with PMH of ESRD (HD Tu/Thu/Sa), T2DM, COPD, chronic bilateral lower extremity wounds, and right BKA admitted for gangrene of R 4th and 5th fingers and calciphylaxis of right hypothenar eminence. Patient complains of progressively worsening pain in right hypothenar eminence and right 4th and 5th fingers of one week duration. She follows with WMC outpatient wound team and was recently evaluated by them. She was also seen by WMC ED yesterday for same chief complaint and was discharged on same day. Patient reports she had her RUE AV fistula reviewed by Dr. Woolard 6 days ago to increase blood flow to right 4th and 5th fingers. She does not report improvement in her symptoms since this intervention. She also complains of night sweats but denies fever and chills and was afebrile in ED. She also complains of nausea. She completed HD today. In the ED, LA was normal and CTA RUE and RUE Duplex US showed heavily calcified distal radial and ulnar arteries with possible hemodynamically significant stenosis. ED provider consulted hand surgeon, vascular surgeon, and nephrologist. Due to gangrene and increased risk of sepsis, patient was started on broad antibiotics. Home plavix held for potential amputation of right fourth and fifth fingers.

PROCEDURE: US UE Arterial Duplex Right.
TECHNIQUE: Multiple real-time grayscale images were obtained over the right
upper extremity in various projections. Additional duplex Doppler and color
Doppler images were also obtained.
INDICATION: 53-year-old female with a right arm dialysis fistula, presents with
right hand and right finger ischemic changes.
COMPARISONS: CTA right upper extremity 2023-07-21
FINDINGS:
The vessels are heavily calcified limiting assessment. There is triphasic flow
in the right subclavian artery with normal flow velocities. Flow becomes
monophasic in the axillary artery where there is elevated flow velocity in the
proximal brachial artery suggesting hemodynamically significant stenosis. There
is diminished flow velocities in the ulnar artery with normal flow velocity in
the radial artery but the waveform is monophasic.
IMPRESSION:
Heavily calcified vessels throughout the right upper extremity. There is
elevated flow velocities in the right brachial artery proximally suggesting
possible hemodynamically significant stenosis. The flow is triphasic in the
subclavian artery but monophasic in the entirety of the right arm including the
axilla, brachial, ulnar and radial arteries.
